title: Fairness in Housework Doesn’t Mean 50/50
text:
Some of my dearest friends and I met in downtown Los Angeles one Saturday morning to join a march to honor breast cancer survivors. As we walked through the streets in pink leggings, chanting, “Courage, strength and power,” it felt like a true girlfriends’ getaway with high-energy sisterhood in the air. That is, until the first text message came through around noon: When are you coming home?

It was from one of our husbands, who had spent the morning with the kids and now was “done,” he said. As we watched our friend type back a response, nearly every woman in the group felt her own phone come to life with a similar message:

When is the babysitter coming?

Where did you put the soccer bag?

What’s the address of the birthday party?

Do the kids need to eat lunch?

Where are Anna’s pants?

The last one was from my husband, Seth. I gave him a call to see what was going on. “Well, I guess we can’t go to the park because you”—he emphasized—“didn’t leave me any clothes.” After 30 calls and 46 texts (I counted them) from the husbands, sitters, neighbors and mothers-in-law who had been called in to rescue and cover for the 10 of us in our absence, one of our group finally said what we were all thinking: “Maybe we should just skip lunch and go home?”

“ Women feel overwhelmed, but the solution isn’t necessarily for their partners to share strictly equally in their efforts at home. ”

Considering my hectic, dual-career household, it didn’t seem right to me to have to leave my preplanned event early over a pair of missing pants. My husband and I always teach our kids to be “fair” and to make things “equal” when they squabble. So why doesn’t “equal” ever seem to work when it comes to sharing family duties in our household?

I decided to dig into the issue. I’m trained as a lawyer, mediator and negotiator, and my whole job is to find win-win solutions to thorny issues, so I put my researcher hat on and went to work. Over the course of several years, I interviewed more than 500 men and women about how they divide responsibilities at home and spoke with a range of experts who have studied the problem.

My chief finding: Women feel overwhelmed, yes. But the solution isn’t necessarily for their partners to share strictly equally in their efforts at home.

True, women continue to do the lioness’s share—two-thirds—of domestic labor in the home, even in two-earner families in which both parents work full-time, according to a 2012 study in the journal Social Forces. And a well-known study from the 1990s, in the American Journal of Sociology, found that the more married women earned compared with their husbands, the less housework the husbands did.

What to do? Here’s a perhaps counterintuitive solution: Instead of setting an unattainable ideal of men doing exactly equal work on the home front, women should ask their partners to completely “own” the jobs that they do take on. Maybe husbands will still do less than wives, but they will do more of their lesser share.

It’s when work gets done partway by each partner, or needs excessive input and oversight from one, that communication—and marriages—break down. A recent survey by researchers at Harvard Business School revealed that 25% of divorced couples listed “disagreements about housework” as the top reason for breaking up. When I asked women what makes the biggest difference in their marital satisfaction, they said that it depends much less on whether tasks are split 50/50 in the household than on whether their partners fully conceive, plan and execute a task.

“I don’t have any grand illusions of my husband doing equal to what I do,” confided one woman from Ann Arbor, Mich., “but I would like him to take responsibility for those things he promised to ‘handle’ and without reminders from me.”

A study by Harvard researchers published this year in the American Sociological Review found that women reported doing more “cognitive labor” at home than their spouses did—such as anticipating needs (the kids prefer mustard to ketchup on their hot dogs), monitoring progress (are we running low on mustard?), identifying options (is the grocery store still open?) and making decisions (Dijon or yellow?). Men often don’t see or value this sort of invisible work until they start to do it themselves.

My interviews with men confirmed what a famous 2005 time-diary study funded by the National Science Foundation found: When they were self-reporting, the men tended to overestimate how much of the domestic work and child care they actually do, because they weren’t factoring in the cognitive labor.

“ Many studies have found that the perception of fairness is a stronger predictor of a healthy marriage than the actual division of labor. ”

But here’s the good news: Among couples I interviewed, once they began to understand every part of what was required to meet a responsibility fully, the sense of fairness shifted. Specifically, when women felt relieved of a share of the cognitive labor, they reported that the division of tasks was more equitable—even when the division was not straight down the middle.

Many studies, including one in 2017 funded by the National Institute of Mental Health, have found that the perception of fairness is a stronger predictor of a healthy marriage than the actual division of domestic labor. Men I interviewed who reported feeling the most confident and invested in their domestic roles were those whose wives trusted them with full ownership of household and child care tasks.

“The idea of ‘fair, not equal’ has already changed the dynamic in my home,” reported one of my early female beta-testers from Los Angeles. “My husband...is now ‘owning,’ not just ‘helping’ with tasks. He already does a lot, but it was typically piecemeal, requiring my input, thus negating any mental relief for me. But now the dialogue has begun, and we talk about what are ‘his’ tasks and what are mine.”

This management-style approach has been helping professional organizations thrive for decades, and it drives the culture at many of the most successful companies today. Apple coined the term “Directly Responsible Individual” to refer to the person with whom the buck stops on any given project. Netflix has its own model: the “Rare Responsible Person.” It’s the ideal team member, someone who doesn’t wait to be told what to do but instead is self-motivated, takes the lead and “picks up trash from the floor.”

All of the thousands of tasks required to create our favorite products and bring them into our homes have benefited from project managers whose job is to conceive, plan and oversee how each one will be completed. They will tell you that they live or die by this model, because it’s the most efficient way to get things done.

If you’re thinking: “Yeah, sure, that works in the professional world, but it’s not the way we do things in our home,” let me stop you. I’ve tested this systems approach with couples from all walks of life—from two-career couples to stay-at-home parents, all across the country, with people of diverse backgrounds and life experiences. I have found that the couples who adhere to this method experience a dramatic shift away from dysfunction, resentment and passive-aggressive behavior and toward more time-saving efficiency and feelings of fairness.

It certainly changed my family for the better when my husband took over managing the logistics of extracurricular sports for my two sons. I gained back eight hours a week. Think about everything that just this one task requires you to anticipate: What equipment do they need? What’s the game schedule? When do you have to provide the team snack? Who’s driving the carpool? Once my husband understood how “ownership” invites a stronger and more fulfilling parenting role, he willingly offered to do more—and without any nagging reminders from me. We both consider this a win.

Your “fair” won’t look like mine, and it will likely change over time. But getting it right isn’t a luxury, it’s a necessity—for a happy home with two happy people who collaborate rather than compete.

—This essay is adapted from Ms. Rodsky’s new book, “Fair Play: A Game-Changing Solution for When You Have Too Much to Do (and More Life to Live),” which will be published by Putnam on Oct. 1. She is the founder of Philanthropy Advisory Group.
description: Happiness at home comes from each spouse owning tasks completely—not dividing everything exactly down the middle.
